Bhanage Conceptualization Methodology Writing - review & editing Supervision Validation Resources Funding acquisition * Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology (ICT), Mumbai, 400019, India Department of Chemistry Institute of Chemical Technology (ICT) Mumbai 400019 India Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology (ICT), Mumbai, India–400019 ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The highly efficient carbon dioxide (CO2) fixation into value-added organic carbonates has gained enormous attention in the last few decades. This work reports, synthesis and characterization of amino acids (AAs) assisted ZnO nano catalyst and Its application for the cyclic carbonates and formamides synthesis with CO2 atmosphere. The prepared catalysts are characterized by IR, SEM, TEM, XRD, DSC-TGA XPS analysis. l-Serine@ZnO exhibits excellent catalytic activity for transformation of CO2 into value-added chemicals namely formamides and cyclic carbonates. The catalytic systems which work in the presence of CO2 balloon atmosphere for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates are rarely explored. This catalytic system shows excellent activity under the CO2 balloon atmosphere for carbonate synthesis. The developed methodology demonstrates broad substrate scope as well as excellent functional group tolerance for carbonates and formamides synthesis. Additionally, the synthesized catalyst was recyclable up to five recycling runs without considerable loss in its catalytic activity, thus makes this protocol cost-effective and sustainable. Keywords Cyclic carbonate Formamide L-Serine@ZnO Heterogeneous catalyst CO2 balloon pressure Epoxides Amines PMHS 1 Introduction The massive emissions of CO2 to the atmosphere represent an ever-growing problem [1] that continues the progress for the capture and utilization (CCU) of CO2 as a C1 source towards value-added chemicals within the chemical community [2–7]. The use of CO2 as an ideal C1 source in synthetic chemistry has gained remarkable attention in the past decades because of its abundance, low cost, renewability, and can potentially serve as an important building block in synthesis of valuable compounds [8–10]. The transformation of CO2 into fine chemicals at atmospheric pressure is exciting both in industry and academia. However, just a fraction of the huge amount of CO2 has been fixed into value-added chemicals and on the other hand, CO2 is thermodynamically stable and kinetically inert, which limits its chemical conversion, especially under mild conditions, is challenging [11–13]. In recent years, CO2 has been transformed into many value-able chemicals like carbonates [14,15], carbamates [16], formamides [17,18], benzimidazoles [19], urea [20], etc; among them, the cycloaddition of epoxides and CO2 to cyclic carbonates were extensively studied in literature. This is 100 % atom economical process which follows the green chemistry principle; thus, this reaction is one of the most attractive way for the CO2 utilization (Scheme 1 ) [21]. Carbonates are extensively used as green polar aprotic solvents, intermediate in various reactions and electrolytes in non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries. Considering the importance of cyclic carbonate, both catalytical systems such as homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been prepared for this transformation. Homogeneous catalysts like metal complexes [22], organo catalysts [23–25], ionic liquids [26,27], ammonium salts [28,29] shows good performance for the cycloaddition of epoxide and CO2, but these catalytic systems require high energy utilization, high economic cost due to separation, purification, and recycling of catalysts, etc. Considering the disadvantageous of homogeneous catalysts, various heterogeneous catalysts have been prepared for cyclic carbonates synthesis like porous organic polymers [30], metal-based catalysts like metal oxides [31,32], metal-organic framework (MOF) [33,34], metal-salen complexes [35,36], Urea-DerivedFramework [37], tri-s-triazine terminal-linked ionic liquids [38], etc. were extensively studied. Recently, Bondarenko et al. reported ZnCl2/Al2O3-TBAI catalyst for efficient conversion of epoxide to cyclic carbonate by using 4 atm CO2 pressure for 16 h [39]. Next, Weisheng Liu and co-workers developed various [Zn4Tb3L4] catalysts for efficient conversion of epoxide and 10 atm CO2 pressure to cyclic carbonate at 120 °C for 8 h [40]. However, these catalytic systems require considerable energy input for an adequate yield of cyclic carbonates, which restricts its application. Therefore, there is a need to develop a more efficient heterogeneous catalyst for effective CO2 transformation under mild conditions is an attractive aim. A previous work clearly shows that the Lewis acidic or basic groups are essential for fixation of CO2 and activation of epoxides. Recently, catalysts having biodegradable components such as amino acids [41–43], amino acids IL [44], hexabutylguanidinium salt and zinc bromide [45], has been reported as effective catalysts to obtained carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. Therefore, Zn+2 with amino acids has become the most attractive catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2. The previous reports having catalysts such as Zn+2 combined with hexabutylguanidinium [45], phosphonium [46], Schiff base [47], imidazolium [48], have shown good catalytic activity. Also, Zn+2 with amino acid has been explored due to its moisture stability, easy preparation and biodegradability. Also, the recent reports show that the catalysts having a carboxyl group [49–51] or hydroxyl group [23–25,52] plays a vital role in the epoxide activation through hydrogen-bonding. Liu et al. have reported that the various sodium amino acid salts are able to capture one Equiv. CO2 by the introduction of CO2 into the NH bond [53]. These recent advances encouraged us to develop efficient multifunctional catalyst which permits activation of epoxide as well as CO2. Amino acids are class of important biomolecules and environmentally friendly natural products that contain both the Bronsted acidic carboxyl group and the basic amino groups which are responsible for CO2 activation. The catalyst, which has Bronsted acidic sites through the introduction of ZnO nano and CO2 activating sites by introduction of amino acid group. To the best of our knowledge, there was no previous report for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides and formylation of amines using amino acids capped ZnO (AAs@ZnO) catalyst. In this work, we prepare various AAs@ZnO catalysts and their application for carbonate synthesis and N-formylation of amines by using PMHS as a reductant. Moreover, the synthesized catalyst showed excellent activities towards the synthesis of cyclic carbonates under CO2 balloon atmosphere. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental procedure 2.1.1 Synthesis of amino acids@ZnO catalysts The typical procedure for the synthesis of AAs@ZnO catalysts is, Zn(OAc)2 (1 mmol) and amino acid (2 mmol) were stirred in 15 mL of deionized water for 15 min. Then 10 mL solution of 1.5 mol NaOH was added in the above solution and stirred this mixture for 5 min. After the precipitation formed, the mixture is placed in a probe sonicator for 15 min and kept in an oven at 100 °C for 8 h and washed with deionized water. Then again, heat in oven at 100 °C for 4 h to obtain ZnO in situ coated with amino acid (AAs@ZnO) catalysts. 2.1.2 Synthesis of cyclic carbonates Propylene oxide (2 mmol), L-Serine@ZnO (10 wt%), TBAI (10 mol%), Acetonitrile (5 mL) were taken in Schlenk tube and CO2 (balloon) was introduced and reaction was heated to desired temperature then stirred for 16 h, cooled it to the room temperature, the AAs@ZnO was regained by centrifugation, dried and reused for next recycled run. The remaining solvent was concentrated in vacuo and product was separated by column chromatography and analysed by using the GC as well as GCMS and NMR analysis. 2.1.3 Synthesis of formamides Amines (1.0 mmol), L-Serine@ZnO (20 mg), PMHS (2 mmol), DMF (5 mL) were added into high-pressure reactor and sealed the reactor then 15 bar CO2 pressure was maintained in reactor, heated to desired temperature, kept for 20 h and cooled the reactor and pressure was slowly discharged from the high-pressure reactor. The AAs@ZnO was regained by centrifugation dried and reused for next recycled run. The remaining solvent was concentrated in vacuo and product was separated by column chromatography and analysed by using the GC as well as GCMS and NMR analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 FT-IR The FT-IR spectra of AAs@ZnO and the recycled catalyst has been shown in Fig. 1 . FT-IR spectrum was recorded from the 400 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1 using KBr pellet. In case of free L-serine peaks observed at 1600 and 1407 cm−1 shows the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of carboxylic group respectively (Fig. 1a). The IR spectra of L-serine@ZnO (shows the peaks at 1354 and 1592 cm−1 correspond to symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of carboxyl group respectively (Fig. 1b). An absorption band at 440 cm−1 was observed and it corresponds to stretching vibrations Zn-O bonds. The broad band peak starts from 3000 to 3600 cm−1 confirms the existence of OH and NH stretching vibration of hydroxy and amino groups of L-Serine@ZnO. The IR spectra of L-serine@ZnO shows the peaks at 3000–3600, 1592, 1354 confirms the successful loading of L-serine on ZnO. Fig. 4e shows the IR spectra of ZnO and the peaks at 440 cm−1 exhibits the stretching vibration of Zn-O bond. Also, there are no significant changes observed in the IR spectra of recycled catalysts (Fig. 1c and d). 3.1.2 SEM SEM and TEM images of L-serine@ZnO catalyst is presented in Fig. 2 . Generally, SEM provides information about the morphology of synthesized catalysts. The L-serine coated ZnO gave the flower-like morphology of L-Serine@ZnO catalyst as shown in Fig. 2a–d. 3.1.3 XRD The XRD patterns of synthesized catalysts and recycled catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3a and b shows the XRD spectra of L-Serine and ZnO. Fig. 3c shows the XRD spectrum of L-serine@ZnO, which confirms the successful loading of amino acid. The most intense peak at 2Ɵ = 36.16° is observed and assigned to the (101) orientation. The intense and sharp peaks of XRD diffraction pattern shows the prepared catalysts were well crystallized. The AAs@ZnO and recycled catalysts were shows the peak of ZnO NPs at 2Ɵ = 62.8°, 56.5°, 47.4°, 36.1°, 34.4°, 31.9° and are well-matched with the lattice planes (201), (112), (103), (102), (101), (002), (100), (110) respectively. This results following earlier reports [54,55]. Additionally, the peaks observed at 31.9°, 34.4°, 36.1° are also suggested that pure wurtzite structure of ZnO nano [56,57]. Moreover, there is no notable variation observed in the XRD patterns of the recycled catalyst after five recycle which confirms the stability of catalyst (Fig. 3d and e). 3.1.4 TGA The TGA graph shows that only 7–8% weight loss during the heating from 30 to 600 °C. The 1 % weight loss was observed from 31 to 100 °C temperature for fresh catalyst (Fig. 4 ). This is attributed to the removal of absorbed moisture. The other weight loss was also noted from 150 °C to 580 °C and this weight loss corresponds to the combustion of organic constituents. This shows that the synthesized catalysts found to be thermally stable. 3.1.5 XPS The XPS of L-Serine@ZnO was presented in Fig. 5 (a–d). The Fig. 5a shows the XPS graph of C 1s. The peak observed at 288 eV in C 1s spectra are attributed to the carbonyl group and another peak at 284.7 eV is ascribed to the CO bond. In the O 1s spectra (Fig. 5b) two peaks ware observed. The lower binding energy peak of 529.7 eV and it indicates to the O−2 ion in the ZnO nanoflowers and another peak at 531.2 eV is ascribed to the hydroxyl group. The N 1s XPS spectra of L-Serine@ZnO clearly shows the peak at 399.6 eV and it corresponds to the amine group of L-Serine (Fig. 5c). Fig. 5d demonstrates the Zn 2p region of L-Serine@ZnO catalyst. In the Zn 2p spectra of L-serine@ZnO, two fitting peaks were observed at 1020.7 eV and 1043.8 eV which ascribed to the Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 respectively. 3.2 Cycloaddition of Carbon dioxide and epoxides to Cyclic carbonates The catalytic ability of AAs@ZnO was examined to obtain propylene carbonate (2a) from propylene oxide (1a) and CO2 as a model reaction (Table 1 ). The influence of various solvents for synthesis of cyclic carbonate was studied (ESI, Table 1). Dimethylformamide (DMF) and Acetonitrile (ACN) gave 74 and 88 % yield of propylene carbonate (2a), respectively. ACN is selected as a solvent for further study. Next, the effect of various catalysts was investigated, and L-Valine@ZnO showed a lower yield of 2a (55 %) while L-Serine@ZnO and L-Proline@ZnO gave the desired product 2a in 90 and 72 % yield respectively (Table 1, entries 1–3). This is probably due to the in L-Serine@ZnO, the hydroxyl group of L-Serine activates the epoxide by hydrogen bonding. L-Serine@ZnO was selected as a catalyst for further experiments. In addition, the effect of co-catalyst was also studied; the catalytic activities of tetrabutylammonium bromide, tetrabutylammonium chloride, tetrabutylammonium fluoride showed lower reactivity for the synthesis of 2a as compared to the tetrabutylammonium iodide (90 %) under same reaction conditions (Table 1, entries 4–6 and 1). Similar trends were also observed for tetraalkylammonium halides in literature. These results clearly indicate that the bromo, chloro and fluro salts gave less yield because they have the ability of the inferior leaving group as compared to iodo group. Tetrabutylammonium iodide was selected as co-catalyst for further experiments. The control experiment was also performed. The reaction was carried out with the only ZnO and only L-Serine as catalyst gave the less yield of 2a (45 % and 35 % yield respectively) compare to L-Serine@ZnO catalyst (Table 1, entries 7, 8 and 1). Also, the reaction was carried out with only tetrabutylammonium iodide (absence of catalyst) gave the 22 % yield at 40 °C for 24 h. To explore the present catalytic system with L-Serine@ZnO as a catalyst, we designed a series of reactions with cumulative variations in catalyst loading, reaction time and CO2 pressure to get best optimal reaction condition First, the influence of catalyst loading was examined and results are presented in Fig. 6 . There is a sharp increase in yield of propylene carbonate was noted when amount of catalyst ranging from 2 to 10 wt%. A further rise in the catalyst amount to 12 wt%, no increase in yield of 2a was observed; thus, 10 wt% catalyst loading is optimized for further catalytic experiments. Subsequently, the effect of CO2 pressure was examined (Fig. 7 ). There is slightly decreased in yield of propylene carbonate was noted from 95 to 90 % when CO2 pressure was reduced from 5 to 1 bar (balloon). The CO2 balloon (1 bar) was used for further experiments. Next, the effect of reaction time was investigated (Fig. 8 ). The yield of PC was sharply increased up to 92 % from 8 to 16 h. Then, a slight increase in yield of PC was noted when time increased from 16 to 24 h. Next, the effect of co-catalyst loading was investigated (Fig. 9 ). The 4 mol% co-catalyst was sufficient to acquire a good yield of propylene carbonate. The final optimized reaction condition is Propylene Oxide (2 mmol), CO2 (1 bar using a balloon), catalyst (10 wt%), TBAI (4 mol%) acetonitrile (5 mL) at 40 °C for 16 h. With the help of effective catalyst and optimized reaction parameters, the scope of the various substrate of epoxide 1a was examined with L-Serine@ZnO catalyst under CO2 balloon atmosphere (Scheme 2 ). Propylene oxide and its derivatives, as well as aromatic epoxides, were also employed to achieve resulting cyclic carbonates 2a – 2 h in good to excellent yields. Epichlorohydrin was utilized for same reaction condition to achieve cyclic carbonate 2b in 90 % yield. 4-((allyloxy)methyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2c) was also synthesized from 2-((allyloxy)methyl)oxirane and CO2 in good yield (89 % yield). On the other hand, the aromatic epoxides gave less yield as compared to aliphatic epoxides under the optimized reaction conditions. Then we increased the reaction temperature to 60 °C, which could provide the desired carbonates (2e to 2 h) in good to excellent yield. The reaction of 1,2-disubstituted epoxides with CO2 was also studied with an optimized reaction condition. The reaction of 1,2-dimethylepoxybutane proceeded smoothly to obtain a 70 % yield of 2i. The reaction of stilbene oxide and cyclohexane oxide progress slowly to achieve respective cyclic carbonate in reduced yield (2 j and 2k). This is probably due to the steric hindrance of two phenyl ring and cyclohexane ring in respective epoxide. The gram-scale synthesis of propylene carbonate (2a) from propylene oxide (1a) and CO2 with the present catalytic system was also demonstrated (Scheme 3 ). The mixture of propylene oxide (40 mmol), L-Serine@ZnO (10 wt%) and TBAI (4 mol%) and acetonitrile (5 mL) was stirred at 40 °C for 16 h in presence CO2 pressure which provided 81 % yield of 2a. A plausible reaction mechanism has been proposed for synthesis of cyclic carbonate catalyzed by L-serine@ZnO based on the previous reports (Fig. 10 ) [57–61]. The L-serine catalyst was prepared in basic condition (pH∼10). The L-serine at pH > 9.15 predominantly exist in anionic form (COO¯ and NH2), which is good nucleophile can form bond with ZnO [62,63]. The L-serine functionalized ZnO having intermolecular interaction among the ZnO and surface bound L-Serine Ligand. The CO2 is activated by amine functional group of amino acid (Intermediate V) and ZnO of L-Serine@ZnO catalyst is helpful to activate the epoxide ring (Intermediate I). The activated epoxide can easily undergo ring-opening by tetraalkylammonium halide to form intermediate II. Then anion of the intermediate II can easily attack the activated CO2 to generate intermediate III. Subsequently, the intermediate III undergoes cyclization reaction to obtained cyclic carbonates, L-Serine@ZnO and tetraalkylammonium halide. Also, there is a noncovalent interaction between the epoxide O and L-Serine@ZnO in transition states I, II and III. The comparisons of the catalytic activity of L-serine@ZnO with other catalysts reported in the literature (Table 2 ). Table 2 exhibits various heterogeneous and homogeneous catalyst used for cyclic carbonate synthesis from CO2 and epoxides. The L-serine@ZnO catalyst shows the comparable or higher catalytic activity as compared to the heterogenous and homogeneous catalysts such as amino acids based catalyst [64–67], Zinc based catalyst [68−78], Cu MOF [79], Co-salen complex [80], u-C3N4 [81], MeNSBA-15 [82], Succinimide-KI system [83], Li-MgO [84], PVA/KI system [85], [Apbim][Glu] [86] etc. Moreover, there are only few catalysts which works at 1 atm pressure such as NHC/ZnBr2, Morpholinium IL and ZnBr2 catalytic system, Co-salen complex etc, which requires higher temperature or time compare our catalytic system. Also, the use of L-serine@ZnO catalyst avoids the use of expensive organic molecules for MOF etc. Additionally, L-serine@ZnO catalyst easily prepared, inexpensive, easily separate form reaction by simple filtration or centrifugation. 3.3 Formylation of amines Encouraged by the successful synthesis of cyclic carbonates by using L-Serine@ZnO as a catalyst under ambient CO2 pressure, we further explored the use of amino acids@ZnO for N-formylation of amines in presence of CO2 for synthesis of formamides. Considering the importance and application of formamides as a solvent, raw materials and versatile constituents in several organic synthesis, also it is used as precursors for formamidines and isocyanides [87,88]. The formamide precursors can show high biological activity in many drug molecules. Conventionally, formamides are manufactured from CO as a carbon source under harsh reaction conditions and sodium methoxide is used as a catalyst [89]. In literature, hydrosilanes have been used for the conversion of amines and CO2 to formamides and methylamines. Recently, PMHS [Poly(methylhydrosiloxane)] attracted much attention as a reducing agent as it is an abundant waste material of silicon industry. Also, it is non-toxic, biodegradable, inexpensive and used as an environmentally friendly reducing agent for CO2 [90]. Molecular hydrogen and hydrosilanes (Si-H) have nearly the same reduction potential as Si-H bond having lower bond dissociation energy and high polarity [91]. However, most of the extant methodologies have disadvantages like the use of expensive metal complexes, toxic reagents (CO or Phosgene), costly metal complexes and need of harsh reaction conditions. Hence, there are ample opportunities to find a new protocol for aromatic and aliphatic amines using CO2 as a C1 source. We herein report, L-Serine@ZnO as a more effective catalyst for synthesis of formamides from amines and CO2 using PMHS as a reducing agent. We explored the formylation of amines using L-Serine@ZnO as a catalyst in presence of Carbon dioxide as a carbon source and PMHS as a reductant. The formylation of morpholine was selected for an optimization study to analyze the catalytic performance of L-Serine@ZnO catalyst in the presence of a CO2 atmosphere (Table 3 ). The influence of different solvents on the yield of formamide was examined (Table 3, entries 1–4). The 1,4-dioxane gave a 90 % yield of the desired product. Thus, 1,4-dioxane was selected as an ideal solvent for further reactions (Table 3, entry 3). The synthesized AAs@ZnO catalysts were studied for the N-formylation of amine, and moderate to excellent yield of formamides was gained (Table 3, entries 3, 5 and 6). L-Valine@ZnO gave only 20 % yield of 4a (Table 3, entry 5) while L-Serine@ZnO and L-Proline@ZnO produce the formylated product in 90 % and 55 % yields respectively using PMHS as a reducing agent (Table 3, entries 3 and 6). No formylated product was obtained when we performed the reaction in absence of any catalyst (Table 3, entry 7). Next, the impact of temperature on reaction system was investigated, as we reduced the reaction temperature to 80 °C, the 4a was achieved in good yield (Table 1, entry 8), further decreased in temperature to 60 °C the yield of 4a was also reduced (Table 3, entry 9). Finally, the influence of CO2 pressure was also explored (Table 3, entries 11–13). The 15 bar CO2 pressure is sufficient to obtain N-formylmorpholine (4a) in 90 % yield (Table 3, entry 12). The optimized reaction condition is Morpholine (2 mmol), CO2 (15 bar), Catalyst (20 mg), PMHS (2 mmol), solvent: 1,4-dioxane (5 mL) at 100 °C for 20 h. Several amine substrates, including aromatic, aliphatic and aliphatic cyclic amines have donating and withdrawing groups were tolerated under optimized reaction condition to obtain the formamides in good to excellent yields (Scheme 4 ). Cyclic secondary amines showed high reactivity and provided corresponding formamides in excellent yield (Scheme 4, 4a-c). A primary aliphatic cyclic amine also provided N-cyclohexylformamide in 84 % yield (Scheme 4, 4d). Aliphatic secondary amines were somewhat sluggish towards the N-formylation reaction and gave corresponding products in adequate yields (Scheme 4, 4e and 4f). The aromatic primary amine like aniline also gave the 84 % yield of formanilide (Scheme 4, 4g). Next, we studied the electronic effect on the aniline and observed that aniline with electron-donating substituents provided a good yield of formylated products (Scheme 4 , 4h) as compared to the withdrawing substituted aniline (Scheme 4, 4i). The N-methylaniline and N-methyl benzylamine reacted very well to furnished 4j and 4k in excellent yield. 4 Recyclability To ensure the recyclability of any heterogeneous catalyst is an important aspect. We examined recyclability of the synthesized L-Serine@ZnO catalyst for both reactions (Fig. 11 ). The catalytic performance remained very good in both the catalytic reaction using L-serine@ZnO as a catalyst and the recovered catalyst was reused up to five recycles without any noteworthy decrease in the effectiveness of the catalyst. 5 Conclusion We have explored a simple, sustainable and cost-effective catalytic route using L-serine functionalized ZnO (L-serine@ZnO) catalyst used for the chemical conversion of Carbon dioxide into five-membered cyclic carbonates as well as formamides. The L-serine@ZnO catalyst is most efficient for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides under the atmospheric pressure of CO2 at low temperature. This catalyst can effectively activate the epoxide through ZnO as well as hydroxyl group of L-serine amino acid and CO2 is activated by amine group of amino acid. This catalyst is recyclable for five successive recycles without losing considerable catalytic efficiency for both the transformation. Furthermore, the L-serine@ZnO catalyst was synthesized from L-serine amino acid as environmentally benign and non-toxic raw material, which is important for the utilization of carbon dioxide. coredata.dc:description: The highly efficient carbon dioxide (CO2) fixation into value-added organic carbonates has gained enormous attention in the last few decades. This work reports, synthesis and characterization of amino acids (AAs) assisted ZnO nano catalyst and Its application for the cyclic carbonates and formamides synthesis with CO2 atmosphere. The prepared catalysts are characterized by IR, SEM, TEM, XRD, DSC-TGA XPS analysis. l-Serine@ZnO exhibits excellent catalytic activity for transformation of CO2 into value-added chemicals namely formamides and cyclic carbonates. The catalytic systems which work in the presence of CO2 balloon atmosphere for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates are rarely explored. This catalytic system shows excellent activity under the CO2 balloon atmosphere for carbonate synthesis. The developed methodology demonstrates broad substrate scope as well as excellent functional group tolerance for carbonates and formamides synthesis. Additionally, the synthesized catalyst was recyclable up to five recycling runs without considerable loss in its catalytic activity, thus makes this protocol cost-effective and sustainable.
coredata.dc:title: L-Serine@ZnO as an efficient and reusable catalyst for synthesis of cyclic carbonates and formamides in presence of CO2 atmosphere
